title: Expect Significant Challenges To The Reflation Narrative: Green
text: Although markets sold off and volatility rose sharply, today's price action was not surprising and can be attributed to market participants waiting until 2021 to take profits. A number of factors, including investors being caught off-guard by taxes and the return of required minimum distributions, suggest that a correction is on the horizon in 2021.

title: Market Recap for Monday, January 4: Stocks sell off on the first day of trading for 2021
text: #stocksselloff #2021stocks #YahooFinance Stocks fell Monday in the first session of 2021, as concerns over a post-holiday spike in virus cases compounded with uncertainty over the outcome of the Georgia Senate runoff elections. Thornburg Investment Management Co-head of Investments Jeff Klingelhofer and Joseph Minarik, The Conference Board Chief Policy Economist & Former OMB Chief Economist under Clinton joined Yahoo Finance Live to break down the details.

title: Russia, Saudis deadlock over whether OPEC should boost crude output: WSJ
text: Saudi Arabia and Russia deadlocked Monday over whether their producers' alliance should boost crude output amid a resurgent pandemic, delegates said after a day of talks ended without a deal.

title: Market Extra: Corporate debt boom resumes as 2021 kicks off
text: Home Depot and John Deere are among a parade of U.S. investment-grade companies that seized on the first trading day in January to borrow in the corporate bond market.

title: Dollar gets respite as virus surge, Georgia runoffs curb risk sentiment
text: The dollar found support as concerns about surging COVID-19 cases and uncertainty about U.S. runoff elections in Georgia fueled demand for safer assets.

title: Cramer reacts to Monday's market sell-off: Fall back on bullish themes
text: "Themes are very useful if you've got some cash stockpiled after last year's remarkable run," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: 2021's Alarm Goes Off for Market Indexes
text: After a terrific 2020 in the equities markets and a continuation in today's pre-market, investors sent the first trading day of 2021's close into the red.

title: The Fed: Economic recovery may be ‘uneven' in 2021, but Fed policy can likely stay unchanged, Mester says
text: Economic growth in 2021 will be uneven, with a slowdown followed by an upturn, but through it all Fed policy can likely remain unchanged, said Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester on Monday.

title: Is the US Dollar About To Collapse or Rally?
text: The U.S. Dollar got hit hard in 2020, declining nearly 7 percent (year over year) and as much as 12 percent from peak to trough during year. This weakness in King Dollar has been a tailwind for commodities and stocks alike.

title: US Indexes Close Lower to Start the New Year
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 30,223.89 on Monday with a loss of 382.59 points or -1.25%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,700.65 for a loss of 55.42 points or -1.48%.

title: Jim Cramer reveals his 10 investment themes for 2021
text: "I always fall back on themes. That's the best way to approach a sell-off, like we had today," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Markets eye uncertainty ahead of Georgia Run-off election
text: CNBC's Ylan Mui reports on tomorrow's Georgia run-off election. With Strategas Research Partners' Dan Clifton, CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Bonawyn Eison.

title: Stock futures flat after S&P 500 suffers first negative start to a year since 2016
text: The moves in futures came after a sharp sell-off on Wall Street to kick off 2021.

title: Stocks Hit Hard by Covid Fears. Why Concerns May Be Overblown.
text: The stock market picked a wonderful way to start the new year—with a reminder that markets really can fall now and again.

title: If stocks kick off 2021 with a correction, market bull Tony Dwyer says buy it
text: Tony Dwyer, Canaccord Genuity, on what to do if this market pulls back. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Bonawyn Eison.

title: 2020 Was Buy The Rumor, 2021 Will Be Sell The News
text: Forecasting is misunderstood by most of the investing public. Investors glom onto forecasts, or belief structures, then do not make the appropriate asset allocation changes when the market signals them.

title: Stocks Stumble as Early Gains Turn to Losses to Start 2021
text: 2021 started right where 2020 left off — robust stock market gains and rising commodity prices in the face of more COVID-19 cases, a new and highly contagious variant of the virus, and political uncertainty. Then things got messy.

title: Wharton's Jeremy Siegel: ‘Dow could easily tack on another 10% to 15%,' but warns of a near-term setback
text: Wharton School finance professor Jeremy Siegel builds his 2021 bull case for stocks.

title: US Market Kicks Off 2021 Significantly Overvalued
text: On Monday, the first trading day of 2021, Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B) CEO Warren Buffett (Trades, Portfolio)'s favorite market indicator stood at 135.1%.

title: The Sovereign Debt Market Ignores Fundamentals
text: Central banks set the rates for their sovereign debt and force banks and insurance companies to buy such debt for regulatory compliance not for their fundamentals. Off balance sheet obligations of countries, while controversial, are likely ignored by markets.

title: In 2021, The Best Dogs In The Dow Are Dobermans
text: Three years ago, I introduced Forbes readers to a stock strategy called the Dobermans of the Dow. This is my annual strategy update.

title: Here's The Biggest Risk For The Stock Market This Year, According To Morgan Stanley Experts
text: It's also the year's biggest investment opportunity.

title: Top ETF themes to watch in the new year, according to two market analysts
text: Dave Nadig of ETF Trends and ETF Database and Harry Whitton of Old Mission flag the trends they see dominating the ETF space in the new year. With CNBC's Bob Pisani.

title: Still Looking Ahead, But.
text: Stocks continue to look ahead to better days. Days when masks and social distancing are no longer needed.

title: Bitcoin ETF: Van Eck CEO on filing again and the cryptocurrency's 2021 prospects
text: Van Eck Associates Corp. CEO Jan Van Eck speaks to his firm's latest proposal for a bitcoin ETF. With CNBC's Bob Pisani, Old Mission's Harry Whitton and ETF Trends' Dave Nadig.

title: Stock Market Today: Stocks Stumble Out of the Blocks to Start 2021
text: The major indices spilled plenty of red ink Monday as investors mulled the consequences of Georgia's upcoming senatorial runoffs, as well as continued COVID woes.

title: Where Is the Growth in 2021?
text: Many of the themes we were investing in 2020 continue into 2021, but there are new drivers for this year as well.

title: We like the markets for three reasons, says J.P. Morgan's Camporeale
text: Phil Camporeale from J.P. Morgan Asset Management says there are three reasons why he likes markets.

title: Keith Bliss on buying opportunities in markets
text: Ketih Bliss, Capital2Market president, says the market has become conditioned to be beat-up due to the effects of the pandemic. He joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss his view on the state of the markets.

title: 2021 Bond Outlook: Will an Uneven Recovery Make Credit Research Even More Important?
text: By Jonathan Rocafort, CFA, Managing Director, SMA Portfolio Management; Bernie Scozzafava, CFA, Director, Quantitative Research and Portfolio Management Vaccines and a proposed stimulus bill figure to give bonds a shot in the arm. But not all sectors will feel it the same way.

title: Market Extra: How does the stock market perform after a 1% drop — or worse — to start a year?
text: Monday's sizable decline in the stock market shouldn't to be taken as an omen of what's ahead for Wall Street after a stellar rebound in 2020, if history is any kind of indication.

title: Dow drops 383 points as COVID-19 cases surge
text: US stocks declined in the first trading session of 2021 on Monday as investors weighed another spike in virus cases. To combat the surge in COVID-19 cases and a new strain of the virus, the UK is entering a full national lockdown until at least mid-February, with most schools transitioning to remote learning.

title: Stocks swoon to start 2021 as lockdowns sweep the globe
text: U.S. stocks fell sharply on the first trading day of the new year as coronavirus vaccine rollouts faltered, case counts rose, and governments imposed fresh lockdowns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 383 points, 1.3%, to close near 30,224, while the S&P 500 fell 55 points or 1.5%, to touch 3,701, based on early estimates.

title: We're a long way from getting comfortable in markets due to the pandemic: Moody's Zandi
text: Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics says if Democrats win the Georgia runoff elections, it's likely to see a large fiscal stimulus package in the summer. He says there needs to be more fiscal stimulus to bring back the markets and to reduce the current unemployment rate.

title: 2021 Outlook For The Long Bond Yield, Equities And The VIX
text: Bond yields may rise during the first half of January 2021, equities should rise, and the VIX may decline. With RobinHooders running rampant, allow for overshoot in terms of time/price. There's a recurring (even persistent) seasonal decline in liquidity flows after the first half of January which persists until the middle of March. This tendency may happen again this year.

title: Why Jefferies' Zervos isn't very worried about the market in 2021
text: David Zervos, Jefferies chief market strategist, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the names he's watching amid the market sell-off.

title: Political worries rattled the market Monday and might not go away soon
text: Apprehension about Georgia's Senate runoff election Tuesday is helping fuel to a sharp New Year's selloff.

title: 4 Reasons The Stock Market Rally Could Resume In 2021
text: The S&P 500 got off to a shaky start to 2021 on Monday. Enrique Abeyta, author of the Empire Elite Trader newsletter, believes there are at least four reasons why investors should shrug off Monday's sell-off and look for the 2020 stock market rally to resume in 2021.

title: Stocks slide from record peaks on Georgia elections, virus surge
text: Shares on Wall Street fell sharply from all-time peaks on the first trading day of the year on Monday, as risk appetite ebbed amid upcoming runoff elections in Georgia and the persistent surge in coronavirus cases. The Dow, which touched a record high earlier in the session along with the S&P 500, was also dragged.

title: Why the Fed's inflation push could turn from friend to foe for the market this year
text: The Fed enters 2021 with a fresh challenge on its plate, namely whether its commitment to higher inflation will poison markets.

title: The market sell off doesn't concern me: Paul Schatz Heritage Capital President
text: Paul Schatz, Heritage Capital President discusses the sell off on the first trading day of 2021.

title: 'Market likes checks and balances,' says strategist on potential Georgia election outcome
text: Andrew Slimmon, Morgan Stanley Investment Management, and John Stoltzfus, Oppenheimer Asset Management chief investment strategist, join 'Power Lunch' to discuss the importance of the Georgia runoff election on the markets and their outlook for 2021.

title: VanEck Files for a Bitcoin ETF All Over Again
text: A bitcoin ETF could finally see the day of the light in 2021 as VanEck recently filed an application with the SEC and the cryptocurrency is also gaining precedence.

title: Cyclical commodities like copper and oil will push prices higher: BofA's Blanch
text: Oil is dropping as the New Year kicks off. Francisco Blanch, BofA Securities, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss the commodity market and why he's not bullish on gold.

title: Sand In My Shoes - December Update
text: The strangest year I've ever lived through closed out strong with nearly every asset class up for the month of December. In addition to the typical month-end charts, tables, and graphs I'll review some year over year figures.

title: Take advantage of potential market opportunities amid sell-off: Wealth advisor
text: CNBC's Kelly Evans breaks down market action on the first day of trading in 2021, and whether the sell-off is more than a market correction, with Katarina Simonetti of Morgan Stanley Private Wealth Management and Doug Ramsey of Leuthold Group. text: Jan.04 -- Jane Foley, head of X strategy at Rabobank, examines the weaker dollar market consensus and says vaccine rollout issues in Europe could become a negative for the euro. She speaks on "Bloomberg Markets: European Close.

title: Janet Yellen made millions giving speeches to Wall Street banks she'll soon regulate
text: Janet Yellen, President-elect Joe Biden's pick for Treasury secretary, made more than $7 million in recent years by giving speeches to Wall Street banks, major corporations and industry groups.
